question: "I know thy works and thy labour and how thou canst not bear them that are evil. And thou hast tried them who say they are apostles and hast found them to be liars". Revelations II.
answer: What the hell does it mean?

question: It means who's side are you on?
answer: You didn't ask me to meet you 30 miles from my office for a Bible study class.

question: It's a bi-partisan issue. Everyone needs to swallow hard. No one, including you, wants to be fingered as the one obstructing efforts to crack down on terrorism, and--
Is that anyway to talk to an old school chum?
answer: You're gonna finger me as soft on terrorism? Terrorism, you unconscionable asshole?

question: There are planes falling out of the sky, buildings blowing up. American buildings. Americans getting bombs in the mail. What are we gonna do!?
answer: We're not gonna hand you and your band of lunatics the keys to the kingdom. I'm not gonna sit in Congress and write a law that allows the NSA to point a camera and a microphone at anything they damn well feel like. And the next time you have something to say to me, we do it above-board, in my office, like everyone else. Now get outa my car, I've got a committee meeting on the hill.

question: I don't know, either, L.T. Maybe you guys should get yourself a labor lawyer. Good point. L.T., in this office I'd prefer you say Italian-Americans. That's because your Union bosses are those Guido mother-fuckers. The Union's trying to railroad you into accepting terms worse than what you have now. Because they've been paid off by Bellmoth. My name's Bobby. I'm your lawyer. Don't do anything 'till I talk to you. Martha! Larry Spinks, St. Lukes. Send him a case of chianti from the firm. And send his wife Rosalie some flowers.
I mean it tastes like every other fish I've ever had. Every fish tastes the same.
Not that much.
answer: Here's what you asked for. Brill's note said it was everything you'd need to, shall we say, coax DePinto--

question: When do I get to meet him?
That wasn't the answer I was hoping for.
"Soon". Or at least sooner than never.
So you've said. Ten thousand cash. I don't know if it's Brill's prices going up or your commission.
answer: I take a straight 15 percent. Brill's fee varies with risk. Perhaps you'd be more comfortable using someone else.

question: Why would I--
answer: Someone with whom you don't have quite so personal a--

question: I like our history. And I like you. I'd probably like Brill if I ever got to--
I just want to make sure I'm not breaking the law.
How can I be sure.
answer: I wouldn't let you. Good luck with DePinto.

question: Mr. DePinto? My name's Robert Dean. I'm an attorney with Seth, Silverberg.
answer: What can I do for you?

question: Well, I was hoping you might stop by my office to swear out a criminal deposition against some of your friends and co-workers.
I don't believe it is, no.
I've got photographs of you at the Trenton Ramada looking very--
It's not?
answer: You don't know who the fuck--

question: That's not you having a whiskey sour with Carmine Morada.
answer: This is fucked. You don't know who's in that--

question: You're right, Mr. DePinto, and maybe I jumped the gun.
answer: You're goddam right you jumped the gun.

question: That's probably not you in the picture. I tell you what, I'll just run the thing by the Grand Jury, see if they can't--
answer: I want to talk to a goddam lawyer.

question: Tell him it's Zavitz. I need to speak to him. Tell him it's important.
answer: Zavitz, what? You want your old job back?

question: Listen to me--
answer: Tired of chasing squirrels around the park?

question: Listen--
answer: Lemme ask you something. I put a bird feeder out in the yard, but the squirrels, they keep taking--

question: Turn on CNN.
answer: They keep taking the bird seed. I thought since you're the expert on--

question: Goddammit, shut the fuck up and turn on CNN!
answer: Alright, I made a joke about squirrels, don't get so--

question: I was doing motion-activated taping up in Shenandoah. That's where Hamersley had his accident. He wasn't alone. He met someone. They argued.
No one. But I'm a little nervous.
answer: When can you get it here?

question: I'm doing a transfer now.
answer: Come straight here. Don't talk to anyone.

question: How're we with pre-trials. Ms. Saunders. Mr. Dean, would you care to give Ms. Saunders a hand with the interrogatories.
answer: God knows I would, sir, but I have a previous engagement this evening.

question: And may I ask what could possibly be more important than Fawell Oil v. U.S. Environmental Agency?
answer: I have to go lingerie shopping. A Christmas present for my wife.

question: Go to Harrison's. They've got models that'll try the garments on for you.
answer: Diane, maybe you didn't hear Mr. Silverberg. They've got models that'll try on the garments. Thank you, sir.

question: Yes? Federal Express? How'd you get in the building? Can you tell me who it's from?
Can you--would it be possible to leave it by the door?
Hm?!
answer: Do you see anything you like?

question: I'm married to my wife...of several years...and I'd like to buy...as a Christmas present...
answer: You'd like to buy your wife some lingerie as a Christmas gift.

question: Yes. I have her permission.
answer: It's okay. I think it's a wonderful gift.

question: I don't know anything about this. Well, I mean, I know a little about--from a certain perspective. My point is, I don't want to do anything foolish.
answer: It's a little late for that.

question: Okay. Daniel? It's me, Robert Dean. From Seth, Silverberg. I worked on--
I'm just doing some Christmas shopping. It's for my wife, no kidding. Though, this isn't the main present, it's just, you know, a little--
Are you okay?
answer: Are you still in Crystal City?

question: Yeah, what's going on?
answer: I think she'll like this very much.

question: Listen, Daniel, hang on one second.
answer: For that matter, I think you will too.

question: Hello. Hello, Maria.
answer: We can't get to the fourth level. We keep getting vaporized by the Black Knight.

question: Hey.
answer: This guy's a fat-assed Rotarian gasbag.

question: Not a very good one, but--
answer: So you tap everyone's phone? You use computers to probe financial records? New Search and Seizure laws?

question: Just for the criminals.
answer: We won't suspend the civil rights of the good people.

question: I think you're taking it seriously enough for both of us.
answer: You're a lawyer. Don't you care what's going on around you?

question: In front of Harrison's, he got hit by a bus. I knew him. The firm did some pro bono work for his organization a few years back.
The thing is, when I saw him, it seemed like he wanted to tell me... ...he was upset about something and he said... Doesn't matter now. I'm gonna wash up.

"Do thou, O Lord, protect us-- --guard us ever from this generation. On every side the wicked prowl, as vileness is exalted among the sons of men." Psalms 12.7 and 12.8. Tell me what this means, Mr. O'Brian. What happened?
answer: He's dead. An accident. Hit by a bus.

question: Am I to understand--
answer: He never made it to the newspaper, but there was private sector contact.

question: Who?
answer: Several indiscriminates and one primary who we've ID'd as Robert Dean. A Crystal City attorney. Mr. Reynolds? Sir?

question: We've checked everything. NRO tapes, traffic surveillance monitors - - and two ATM cameras. The one showing promise, though, is this security camera from the department store. Freeze there. Times ten. Focus on the drop. Enhance, then forward, frame by frame... Just before the view's blocked, Zavitz reaches in his jacket for something. When the view returns, there's a shape change in Dean's bag. See the shadow variance? We reverse imaged it-- Something's definitely been added. It's not a video cassette, the shadow's wrong.
It's hard to say for certain, these things are--
answer: I'm not asking you to say for certain. This is what you're trained to do, right?

question: Zavitz had digital compression equipment. He could've downloaded into something. A disk, a chip, anything small enough to put in his pocket and run with. Whatever he put it in, he dropped it in that bag.
How'd you get the information on DePinto?
Who did you work with to get the--
answer: A guy named Brill. Same guy as always.

question: Yeah, but you said you've never met him. How did you--
answer: Honey, I don't like to talk about this stuff in front of Eric.

question: Have you been working with Rachel?
Oh my God -
answer: This is Robert Dean at 3325 Sutton Place. I want to report a break-in. They took the espresso machine. The espresso machine, Jerry! Which makes sense, you know, because the crooks probably wanted to make themselves a latte before fencing the stereo.

question: This is Robert Dean at 3325 Sutton Place. I want to report a break-in. They took the espresso machine. The espresso machine, Jerry! Which makes sense, you know, because the crooks probably wanted to make themselves a latte before fencing the stereo.
No.
answer: You've got a bunch of Armani suits, they didn't take 'em?

question: Why don't you give 'em a call.
They didn't take the jewelry. They took the computers. They took the big-screen TV, they took my blender.
No, but they took my blender.
answer: Sounds like they didn't want anything that wasn't electric?

question: Serve the ball. Yes?
answer: I didn't want to bother you during your racquetball game.

question: Hey, did you guys find my stuff?
The robbery.
answer: No, sir, I'm not involved with that. I'm doing a quick follow-up on a bus accident took place a few nights ago. Your name keeps coming up.

question: Oh...yeah, I didn't see the accident.
answer: Witnesses said you were there, but I notice you didn't file a report.

question: That's 'cause I wasn't there.
answer: You weren't at Harrison's Department Store the night before--

question: I was in the store, the accident was outside. It was a bus.
answer: Someone said you spoke to Mr. Zavitz before he died. I thought you might know something.

question: I'm no expert, but I'm assuming that the impact of a moving bus against his body caused--
I'm not his attorney.
answer: Than why can't you tell me.

question: Because I don't know.
answer: I'm just trying to determine if Mr. Zavitz was involved in something more than a simple bus accident.

question: Than why don't you talk to the bus driver?
I'm happy to help you all I can. But I didn't see the accident and I barely knew Daniel Zavitz. I've gotta go to work.
Yes, for my wife, what the hell kinds of questions are these.
answer: I thought maybe it might be for Rachel Banks.

question: I don't know what's goin' on with Zavitz, but that was way, way outa line. You understand?
answer: Yes sir. 403 to 401. He's coming up.

question: Hey. Would you get me what I need for Zwernickii and the Bellmoth motions. And do me a favor. Find out what you can about Daniel Zavitz. We did some work for him a few years back and there should be a file.
answer: Dick Burns got a phone call this morning from someone wanting information on you.

question: The police?
answer: No. He said they were doing a credit check. Are you refinancing a loan?

question: He got hit by a bus.
answer: What does that have to do with you?

question: I don't know.
answer: You think there was a connection to--

question: Jesus! I just told you. I don't know.
Yeah?
answer: We'd like to ask you some questions about Daniel Zavitz.

question: Who are you people?
answer: I'm an investigator with Pro-Tech Security.

question: I went through this with an investigator this morning. If I could--
answer: Mr. Zavitz was involved in an extortion scheme. We believe he passed you sensitive materials, possibly with your knowledge, and we need to--

question: You're wrong.
answer: We have good reason to believe that he passed you--

question: If he passed me materials, I'd have them. I don't.
answer: We'd like to recover any materials Mr. Zavitz may have given you--

question: Otherwise you may have to what?
Fuck you. You may have to what? He didn't give me--
Otherwise you may have to what?
Can I talk to you a second?
That's what I want to talk to you about?
answer: I wrote a check for a thousand dollars. You guys didn't have a table that was in the kitchen?

question: The Congressman's very happy to have your support, but he's heard that there's an investigation.
answer: An investigation? It was a bus accident.

question: Your Bellmoth case. The FBI thinks there might be mob ties.
answer: I'm a labor lawyer. There are always mob ties.

question: There's just, clearly, some administrative snafu. I'm sure this is the worst of it. Yeah.
answer: I got a call from my firm this morning saying don't come in.

question: Why?
answer: There are reporters wanting to know about my relationship with you and how long I've worked for the mob. The mob, Bobby!

question: Brill.
answer: Why don't you just call Brill directly.

question: I don't know who he is.
answer: I'm told you had an affair with Rachel Banks four years ago.

question: Told by whom?
answer: Considering the enormous exposure to which you've subjected this firm, I'd think you'd do best to simply answer my questions.

question: Well considering what a colossal douche bag you are, David, maybe I'd do best to simply kick your ass all over the capitol.
This is bullshit. Someone's mixing up a bunch of half-truths to ruin me and to ruin my case.
Maybe Bellmoth. Maybe the unions. I don't know.
answer: Well until we find, you're gonna have to take a leave of absence.

question: You're firing me.
answer: A leave of absence. Until we've sorted this all out.

question: Put David on it. He seems anxious to clear my name.
Fuck off. Stacy! Where's Stacy? What are you talking-- Why? Stacy?
answer: How could you let me find out like this?

question: Stacy, I found out like this. This is the first I'm hearing of--
It's not true.
answer: "Sources revealed an FBI investigation into a possible money laundering scheme that may have sent millions of dollars--

question: I've seen it.
answer: "At the center of the investigation are well-known Washington-area attorneys Robert Dean and Rachel Banks."

question: I have lunch with Rachel once a month. She's my connection to an investigator.
answer: I told you I didn't want you seeing her.

question: I know.
answer: You had an affair with this woman, Robert, we went to a fucking counselor for a year.

question: I see her for business.
answer: You told me you weren't seeing her at all.

question: I didn't want you to be upset. I shouldn't have lied. Stacy, there's nothing between me and Rachel Banks.
answer: The date stamp on the picture is last month. Is that where you and Rachel conduct business.

question: It's not real... That's not me.
It's not a real picture, Stacy, it's been doctored-up.
answer: I think you should leave now, Robert.

question: I'm sorry, sir, this card's been declined.
I'm sure we can locate it for you, sir.
answer: Don't count on it. God Dammit!

question: This is Bobby Dean, the Jew lawyer who squeezed DePinto.
Oh.
answer: My wife's Jewish. But that probably doesn't matter right now.

question: I'll see if I can, you know, work things out.
answer: Well we'd sure like to help you.

question: Why not?
answer: Because we, and our associates, have paid out hundreds of thousands of dollars to shyster lawyers like you, because of shyster lawyers like you, and we'd just as soon sit back and sip a beer while you get ass-banged by as many people as possible.

question: I know, but-- That's my point. Well, I need to find out as much about Daniel as possible. Because my life is being ruined. Rachel?
answer: Good. You're just what I need right now.

question: You got a minute?
answer: It's really not a good idea for me to be seen with you.

question: No. No problem. Outside. There's a lot of people asking questions about you and me.
The IRS contacted me this morning. They say my lifestyle and receipts exceed my income.
For the last four years.
answer: My firm'll represent you. Free of charge.

question: You don't work there anymore, Bobby.
Fuck you. When you needed information, I got it. You didn't care how.
This conversation's over.
answer: What're you gonna do, Rachel? You gonna sit in a bar in Baltimore? You want your job back? You want a life?

question: I don't have a life, Bobby. I'm in love with a married man.
What makes you think it's you?
You're a moron, you know that?

When I need to reach Brill, I chalk the mailbox on 14th and Main. When he sees the mark, he knows there's a drop. The location's always the same. The number twelve ferry to Glen Burnie. Tuesdays or Fridays. The drop's behind Seat 74. I leave something, he picks it up later.
answer: Any idea what he looks like?

question: My guess is male, somewhere in his 40's or 50's. Race, height, weight, you're on your own. Now I don't know how he's gonna feel about someone tracking him down. He's reclusive. I'm sure he has his reasons.
Jesus! What?! You want money?!
answer: Shut the fuck up. Your shoe.

question: Brill? It started with the information you gave me on DePinto. After we talked, he agreed to resign. Next, a phony detective asked me about Daniel Zavitz. Then an investigator questioned me about an extortion scheme they claimed Zavitz was behind. The FBI started looking into mob connections. A doctored picture in the paper. Overnight, I'm ruined. Wife. job, bank accounts, everything gone. Oh Jesus. I don't know anything about Zavitz. They said he was behind an extortion scheme. Yes. Nothing. Nothing. I'm telling you, I-- I just gave him my card. Nothing. Two nights later I was robbed. I'm pretty sure they were pros. Um...who's that? Someone else? Who are you calling?!
Stacy, don't hang up.
answer: Do you know what I'm looking at Robert?

question: Stacy--
answer: I'm looking at a picture of you and Rachel taken yesterday.

question: No, I was with her yesterday. I want you to take Eric and go to our parents house. I want you to do it right now.
answer: I went to the grocery store. My ATM and credit cards didn't work. I couldn't buy food.

question: I know.
answer: I went to the bank to see why. They said you emptied our accounts--

question: It wasn't me.
answer: This is science-fiction Robert! The manager showed me the transfer notice with your signature on it.

question: Stacy, somebody's trying to kill me. Now goddamit--
answer: My father's put me in touch with an attorney. He'll be--

question: Hey!
answer: Forget me, forget what I did for you. Don't ever mention my name or try to contact me again. Get it?

question: I don't know you, I don't know your name, I don't know what the hell you did for me except hang up on my wife and slam me into a wall, but I'm getting pretty fuckin' sick of this! Get it?!
You're Brill.
answer: You knew the deal. No contact.

question: Who was that other guy?
answer: One of many people who would live a word with you.

question: Who are they?
answer: You've heard of the National Security Agency?

question: What do they have to do with this?
Wait.
answer: You drive a black BMW, license plate SRK1339?

question: Yeah.
answer: I clipped this from your wheel well just before they towed your car away.

question: I don't know what that means.
answer: Like a LowJack, but two generations ahead of what the police use. It pulses at 230 Giga-Hertz.

question: I don't know what that means.
answer: 230 Giga-Hertz. They use that band for the Aquacade Spy-SAT uplinks.

question: I don't know what that means.
answer: It means the NSA can read the time off your wristwatch.

question: Why are they after me?
answer: If I knew, they'd be after me. Which they probably are right now. 'Bye.

question: Wait. What do I do?
answer: Pal, you're cooked. It's over. What you did, who you were...that's done. I'd find a quiet job somewhere shoveling snow.

question: Why don't they just identify themselves and tell me what they want?
I don't know what that--
answer: Exposure. They can't have it. They wanna learn what you know and then deal with it.

question: What am I gonna do?! I mean, like, for the rest of my life?!
answer: Hey, if you live another week I'll be impressed.

question: What if--
answer: Look, you gave me some work over the last year. We'll call it even.

question: What if I find out what they're after. You know these people, I don't.
I'll pay you.
answer: They froze your accounts. Get outa my way.

question: I've got a hundred-thousand dollars in jewelry in a safe-deposit box under a third party name. How many years have you been hiding from them? How many years have you been running? What'd they do to you?
answer: If you find something, chalk the Baltimore Sheraton mailbox and go to Temperanceville. It's South of Salisbury. And take this.

question: I'm confused about something. Maybe you can help me out. I sit on top of the greatest intelligence gathering organization in human history. Why can't I bring in a man whose name is in the fucking phonebook?!
He's clever? He had help? Oh.
No, no, I'm sorry. I didn't realize you were hoping to be transferred to a weathership outside Greenland.
I don't care if he's Solomon with Saint Joseph sitting in his lap. I want the tape and I want him. Now is-- Yes?
No thank you.
answer: I also have tiny pizzas and mushrooms stuffed with--

question: Do I look like I want a tiny pizza?
It's the NSA. They're the ones doing this.
The NSA's doing this 'cause they think I have something. And they killed--
My stuff's all over her apartment.
You gotta--
answer: No, listen to me. You gotta let me bring you in.

question: No, I--
answer: You gotta let me bring you in to the police.

question: I won't make it to the police. They won't let me get there. You go.
To the NSA. Make a deal. Tell 'em to stop. Tell 'em I don't have what they're after. Make a deal.
answer: Bobby, you're in way over your head.

question: Listen to me. The house is bugged. So we gotta be quiet, okay? Is Eric in school?
Has anyone been by? Police? FBI?
I wish you'd gone to your parents like I asked you.
answer: This is my house. Nobody's kicking me out of my house. I picked those drapes.

question: I don't think anybody wants the drapes, Stacy, I think the drapes are okay.
I was in a car chase and a small explosion. Now listen to me
Stacy--
answer: I told you they could do this. I told you they had this kind of capability and that with this anti- terrorism it would be just another--

question: Stacy...Stacy...maybe now isn't the best time for the I-Told-You-So speech.
answer: I'm sorry I didn't believe you.

question: That's okay.
answer: I opened the present you got me from Harrison's.

question: You're as bad as Eric. I've got an entire family of people who root through-- ...who root through...uh...presents, and...
Where've you been?
answer: Having an adventure. I can't tell you about it right now, but I'll tell you about it soon.

question: Are you and mom getting a divorce?
answer: No. We're never getting a divorce. We were having a fight. It happens sometimes.

question: Who won the fight?
answer: Men don't win fights with women, son, I'll tell you about that sometime, too. In the meantime, I've got a question for you, and it's incredibly important that you tell me the truth. Under no circumstances will I be angry with you. This is a total Get-Out-Of- Jail-Free card. Ready?

question: Yeah.
answer: Did you take anything--anything at all--out of those Christmas bags I brought home last week.

question: Hey, Mr. D., what's happenin'?
answer: Dylan, I was just asking Eric if--

question: Oh, God, I knew it was stupid, I knew we'd get caught. But the Gameboy was just sitting there. Right on top of the bag. Yes. Yes. We took the GameBoy out of the bag, but with every intention of putting it back.
answer: You're a tough nut to crack, Dylan.

question: I taped it off the 11 o'clock news.
answer: And you were worried about me. That's nice, I appreciate--

question: I was worried about my hundred and twenty 'K'.
The price rises with the temperature and right now you're smokin'. But you're right, you should shop around and get the best price. I'll just let you out here.
I mean did you call anyone.
You don't get it. They go through your phone records. They fuckin' monitor everyone you called in the last--
Oh, I'll bet that threw 'em off the scent. I sure hope you covered the mouthpiece with a handkerchief and used a funny voice!
answer: I don't hear anything. Maybe you're wrong.

question: A hundred and fifty. It's a consumated marriage. The NSA's been in bed with the entire tele-communications industry since the 40's. They've infected everything
answer: How do you know so much?

question: None of your business.
answer: You used to work for 'em, didn't you?

question: I was a traffic analyst. I intercepted phone calls.
answer: How'd you get around the tap orders?

question: They can tap anything as along as it's an airwave intercept. Cellulars and pagers your kid can do. Hard-line calls we'd pick off the relays as they were being fed into ground cables or fired up to the SATs. We'd suck in everything. All foreign, most domestic. Domestic was my group. Druggies, radicals, loud-mouths. Anyone we wanted.
answer: How'd you have the manpower to--

question: Meade has 18 underground acres of computers. They scan every phonecall for target words like "bomb" or "President". We red-flag phone numbers or voice prints...whatever we wanted. When the computers found something, it was bounced to comparative analysis.
That was twenty years ago. With digital? They can suck a salt grain off a beach.
It was '72. I figured we had enough problems without monitoring a Berkeley kid's class schedule. So I sold my story to Ramparts and split.
Well...there'd be too much disclosure to prosecute me. So they ruined my records and made sure I'd never hold a real job again. What do you think?

Welcome to Santa's Workshop. I call it the jar. No phone or utility lines going in. Self-contained. Unplugged from the world. Nothing for a wire bug to piggy- back in on. That leaves only transmitters and signal sweep for those. Now let's see what we got. That is one ugly sunrise.
answer: It really is. Did you find anything?

question: Yeah. Take a walk with me. Remember when Senator Hamersley died in an accident up near Shenandoah?
Well, actually, you have proof. Could you walk a little faster please.

In the warehouse. They're hiding in a duct on the third floor. When we go back inside, they're gonna kill us. When they notice that we're moving toward the car, they'll come running out of the building.
answer: 'Kay, well, could you walk faster, please.

question: Empty 'em 'till they're almost flat. And turn your head. There might be some debris flying your way.
They shouldn't have come without calling first. Where's your gun?
answer: Back at the warehouse. Gimme that.

question: Those are Feds.
answer: I didn't see a warrant. Did you see a warrant?

question: Think we let out enough air?
Fuckin-A.
answer: Let's not do the tire thing anymore, okay?

question: Yeah, I can see where that'd-- These guys are incredibly persistent.
Drive.
answer: Tell him we're not gonna hurt him.

question: Drive or I'll blow your fuckin' head off.
Goddammit--
answer: We're honest people and we need your help. I'll give you two- hundred dollars if you-- Actually, I don't have two-hundred dollars.

question: We found two sets of latent prints in the rubble of Brill's studio. One was Dean's. The other, we believe, belongs to Brill.
And they have the video. That's confirmed.
If they've looked at the video.
answer: Oh, let's assume that they have.

question: If he's with Lyle it means he's got resources.
answer: Resources, that's a good point. He's got resources. All we've got is a six-hundred billion dollar organization! Now goddammit, Hicks, you find 'em. You find 'em and you end it now!

question: We'll take the tape directly to CBS. I'll hand it directly to the News Department.
answer: Listen to you, "directly". You're not gonna get near the News Department. And if you did, it'd never get on the air. Time-Life buried the Zapruder film for 15 years.

question: So what do we do now?
answer: I was thinkin' about asking for my hundred and fifty grand and calling it quits.

question: What if we do a mailing to Congressmen.
answer: It'd never get through. All packages are screened, x-rayed and then hand-searched for explosives. You didn't like my "give-me-my- money" idea?

question: What if we hand deliver to their homes or office?
answer: The area's wired for surveillance, they'll be looking for those moves.

question: Well how do I know what they're--
answer: I know. I know what they're looking for and I'm telling you.

question: But maybe if there were no phone line-- What if we transmitted it over cellular?
Nah, they'd shut down the pin number.
If they couldn't do that, they'd shut down the whole system, all the relays.
They've done it before. Takes maybe two minutes.
What if what?
answer: What if we just fucked with 'em?

question: How?
answer: Same way they did with you and me. We take their biggest guy and turn him into one of us.

question: Who?
answer: Senator Sam Albert, senior Republican. Very well respected. We'll play the NSA's game only we'll play it badly.

question: You wanna get caught spying on Albert?
answer: No, I want the NSA to get caught spying on Albert. We're gonna lead Albert by the nose to one conclusion. And then when he's pissed as hell, we're gonna drop the tape in his lap. How fast can you teach me what I need to know?

question: We'll have to re-stock some basics. Bugs, frequency scanners, contact mics, transmitters, pin-holes, fiber optics-- What do you know about locking cellular phone signals?
answer: I know my phone number and I know the number for SportsPhone. Beyond that--

question: Shit. A 'modified' OKI 900 interfaced with a lap-top creates an enormously powerful tool. I got into the software, did some code re-writing and turned it into one of the best scan-looking systems around. This is every call on the grid. I can lock and position any one I want and follow the hand-offs in real time. Need a place to stay for the weekend? A new TV?
All from a hundred dollar scanner at Radio Shack. But it's time for business.
What happened to you last night?
answer: Christa found it last night attached to her TV. It's a listening device.

question: Jesus H.--
answer: We should everything checked. There's a company in Cambridge called Baudmore. They're discreet.

question: Who's calling?
answer: It's Pat Cary. I work for Senator Sam Albert and I was given Jerry's name.

question: Jerry's on vacation 'till Monday. I can give him the message when he gets back. That was Patrick and the last name--
answer: The thing is...it really can't wait.

question: My name's Neil. Maybe I can help you. Oh yeah. Got another one here. Nasty fella. A TX-703. Remote on- off, three-thousand foot range. Shit, you could listen from a shopping mall across the street. Well, sir, I'm afraid it's not as simple as that. Your average newspaper guy or Hard Copy lady or whatever, they can't buy this stuff.
Ah, sir, you know, it's not for me to say.
answer: What do you mean? Who can buy this kind of equipment.

question: The thing is, Senator, and I don't want to get in the middle of nothing, but--
Most of this stuff's only available to law enforcement.
I yanked this off your RV. It's a Global Positioning Tracker.
Tracks your location to the inch and works directly with--you know...
With spy satellites. I don't like saying these things Senator...
answer: Neil, thank you for your help.

question: Anytime.
answer: This is Sam Albert. Put me through to Langley. Dick Marshal's office.

question: Does Shaffer look stupid to you?
The fuck do you have goin' on with Sam Albert?
answer: This guy's carrying the flag for the damn terrorism bill. You think this is the best time to piss him off?

question: You have any idea what kind of position this--
Jones had to flee the scene before we could locate the second body.
We think it was on Brill. If it was, it's destroyed now.
answer: And if it wasn't? Peace be with you...Peace be with you.

question: I'm Robert Dean. Within twelve hours, you're gonna be in jail. Peace be with you.
answer: Robert, is it safe to be talking on the phone like this?

question: I've re-routed the call. They can't trace it.
Yeah.
answer: They're saying you killed that policeman.

question: Yeah.
answer: Found him. Kent Island nailed the call five minutes ago. He's stationary.

question: Do you have visual?
answer: Not yet. He's near "M" and 34th. I've got an ELSUR unit on the scene now. A residential building. Twelve units.

question: What's your ETA?
answer: Three minutes. We're going in light. Myself and two others. Everyone else is held back in reserve.

question: He walked right up to me in church. At the holiest time of the wear. He approached me in a sanctified place. Kill him now.
I see.
answer: It's actually DH-1 Digitech Pinpoint scanning with a frequency modulator.

question: I don't know what that means.
answer: Me neither, but the upshot is I've got color live-action footage of you and Ms Hawkins and it doesn't look good.

question: So...how much money do you want in exchange for not ruining my life?
answer: I don't want any money. And believe me, I have no interest in ruining your life. I'm not interested in this tape.

question: Yeah.
answer: Sir, we've just intercepted an FBI communication.

question: Well...what is it?
answer: Well, sir, it seems there's a warrant out on--

question: Albert's gonna get me my job back.
Yeah. I wish you could've met...
A friend of mine. I don't know his real name. He's dead now.
